body:
What you want are session cookies but I don't think any browser allows you
to override what the website sends.

On Sat, Mar 14, 2015 at 1:20 PM, Marcus Ferrario notifications@github.com
wrote:

> The atom-shell webview element is storing cookie data. Shouldn't all
> cookie data be removed as soon as the webview is destroyed? Example:
> opening google login in a webview, when opening the webview again in a
> later session it still shows the suer as logged in. Would it be possible to
> add an option for this, if it isn't an error?
> 
> 窶能n> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/atom/atom-shell/issues/1244.

A better answer for your request:  Inject some javascript that runs when
the webview opens.  Put code in to erase all cookies.  Google "clearing all
cookies with javascript".

On Sat, Mar 14, 2015 at 2:35 PM, Mark Hahn mark@hahnca.com wrote:

> What you want are session cookies but I don't think any browser allows you
> to override what the website sends.
> 
> On Sat, Mar 14, 2015 at 1:20 PM, Marcus Ferrario <notifications@github.com
> 
> > wrote:
> > 
> > The atom-shell webview element is storing cookie data. Shouldn't all
> > cookie data be removed as soon as the webview is destroyed? Example:
> > opening google login in a webview, when opening the webview again in a
> > later session it still shows the suer as logged in. Would it be possible to
> > add an option for this, if it isn't an error?
> > 
> > 窶能n> > Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> > https://github.com/atom/atom-shell/issues/1244.

I attempted that however HTTP cookies can't be overwritten. I'm looking for something more like "incognito" for the web view element

窶能nSent from Mailbox

We currently don't have any session related APIs, it is currently tracked at #959.
